Most succint gameplay experience I've ever had. Has a tone completely uniquely dystopian, as while it technically has sign of being dystopian, the lack of human interaction accompanied by the robotic voice of GLaDOS creates this beautiful unnerving feeling that never gets bad enough to be scary. The game does a great job teaching you what you need to know then having you apply your newfound knowledge. Once you have mastered what it can provide, the game ends. It doesn't try to stretch out its playtime because to do so would harm more than help.

Realistically, if you are reading this, you generally know about Portal. It's a 3d puzzle game that provides an interesring mechanic you have to reshape your thinking around. It is, in a sense, groundbreaking for its thought to put the player within the puzzle as a moving component rather than an outside observer.

If you want to get into gaming, just play this, there is very little to dislike, if anything.

13 years later and this game is still amazing. Its core mechanics will remain fun and intriguing forever. This is a game I keep coming back to, and will continue to replay, just because of the pure craftsmanship that went into delivering such an incredible game. I recommend this game to absolutely everyone, from hardcore gamers to casuals and even non-gamers, it has such broad appeal and intuitive concepts that make this one of the greatest games I have ever played.

This game is amazing. It's my 2nd favorite game ever honestly, right behind Portal 2. I love this series and I love this game so much, even though I have the puzzles memorized, even though I can play the game in my sleep I still have so much fun with this game. I remember the first time I played this game and how badly I wanted to play the second game, for context, I had just bought the Valve pack and I wanted to play through the Half Life series, I played this and instantly loved it, I felt like I could never play a game again and I would be happy. I recommend this game to literally everyone. I don't care if it's your first game. It's amazing. If you haven't played this game before buy it, buy the Valve pack even and play all the Half Life games.
Portal deserves all the praise it always got. It's truly a classic.

If you have it big, this game is for you and if you have a small one, don't you worry, this game will enlarge it by several units. I am talking about brain of course. Go ahead, get it.

Portal is a three dimensional puzzle platformer.

This classic uses source engine's groundbreaking physics, allowing you to pick, drop and toss objects, or gain momentum from falling and perform some high speed long distance jumps across the room.

There's not a lot of story here. Being dropped in a futuristic lab setting, you're forced to go through some tests. Throughout your journey, you're accompanied by an AI's voice, which can be really entertaining and funny. It starts off quite friendly and welcoming, but the more you advance in this world, and the more you explore, you find out about other test subjects' stories and realize you might be in trouble.

Each puzzle, or "test chamber", is unique and forces you to think, plan and execute with precision. The first few chambers act as tutorial levels, slowly introducing the game's mechanics, and increasing the complexity & difficulty at a reasonable rate. You traverse the world by walking, jumping and moving through walls and floors using portals created by a special weapon. This weapon can shoot at specific surfaces (usually in plain white), opening up to two portals at a time. Having the portals bound to MB1 & MB2 and each having a different color, is a very wise design choice. The player doesn't have to read or memorize anything, and can focus solely on aiming and timing his portals, which in turn, opens the game up to some high paced action. Generally, I've found the main playthrough challenging, but not too hard. Hardcore players would enjoy the "advanced" bonus content - that's where the game gets really tough and punishing.

The game's graphics and models have aged pretty well, for the most part, except for some ugly toxic water and metallic pipes. The colors are bright and relaxing, but get dark and claustrophobic as you progress.

All in all, the game is very enjoyable, even in 2020. It can be finished in a single sitting, but achievements and bonus content will keep you playing a bit longer.
